title: MBTA announces service changes and suspensions for March
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: MBTA will suspend service on Orange Line and four Commuter Rail lines for signal upgrades in March.
Orange Line service will halt between Back Bay and Forest Hills from Feb. 28 to March 8, with shuttle buses available.
Commuter Rail lines, including Fitchburg, Haverhill, Lowell, and Newburyport/Rockport, face weekend suspensions for signal system improvements.

title: Rafael Devers reacts to Red Sox exec’s ‘pick up a glove’ comment
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Rafael Devers was traded from the Red Sox to the Giants in June 2025 after a strained relationship.
Red Sox chairman Tom Werner criticized Devers for refusing to play first base after an injury to another player.
Devers, now with the Giants, declined to comment on Werner's remarks, stating he wanted to leave the past behind.

title: Adam Schefter maps out potential price for Patriots in Maxx Crosby trade
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots interested in trading for Raiders' Maxx Crosby, a Pro-Bowl pass rusher, despite Raiders' reluctance to trade him.
Adam Schefter suggests Raiders would demand a Micah Parsons-type package, potentially including first-round picks, for Crosby.
Crosby's discontent with Raiders involves alleged tanking concerns and tension with wellness coordinator Alex Guerrero.

title: Fleet’s Aerin Frankel, Team USA ready for yet another gold-medal showdown against Canada
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Team USA will face Canada in the Olympic women's hockey gold-medal game, marking their seventh meeting since 1998.
Boston Fleet's Aerin Frankel has allowed only one goal in 68 shots through four games at the 2026 Olympics.
Team USA defeated Canada 5-0 in group play, with Hilary Knight leading a team including rookies Bilka, Heise, and Murphy.

title: What Steve Kerr, Al Horford said about adding Kristaps Porzingis to the Warriors
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Warriors acquire Kristaps Porzingis from Hawks in a trade two weeks ago; his debut with the team is uncertain.
Steve Kerr expects Porzingis to fit easily, highlighting his proficiency in post-up plays and individual scoring abilities.
Al Horford mentions team focus on improving as they await full roster health, highlighting Porzingis and Stephen Curry's roles.

title: A Malibu Barbie Café pop-up is coming to Boston
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: The Malibu Barbie Café pop-up will open April 17 at 101 S. Market St. near Faneuil Hall, Boston.
The café, inspired by 1970s Malibu Barbie, features a fast-casual menu designed by 'MasterChef' finalist Becky Brown.
Tickets cost $25 and include food and merchandise credit, available exclusively through Bucket Listers with a waitlist open.

title: Baystate Health will no longer prescribe hormones to trans youth
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Baystate Health will stop prescribing hormones to transgender youth under 18, citing threats to Medicaid and Medicare funding.
The Springfield-based system will continue mental health counseling but transfer hormone prescriptions to Transhealth or other providers.
This decision follows New England's trend of health centers reassessing gender-affirming care amid new federal and state regulations.

title: Gloucester struggles for answers as search for sunken fishing boat continues
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The fishing boat Lily Jean sank off Gloucester on January 30, 2026, with seven presumed dead.
Authorities, including Massachusetts Environmental Police, are using sonar and other tools to locate the sunken vessel.
Gov. Maura Healey expressed condolences and emphasized the state's support for the families of the lost crew.

title: A new hotel has been approved in Boston’s Seaport
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: DGH Hotel Partners will build a 15-story hotel with 438 rooms on Anchor Street in Boston's Seaport District.
The hotel is part of a campus with neighboring Aloft and Element hotels, totaling 968 guest rooms in the area.
The project, approved by the Boston Zoning Commission, aims for LEED Gold Certification and will include retail spaces.

title: $22m Beacon Hill townhome sale sets Boston’s single-family home sale record
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Beacon Hill townhome at 46 Chestnut St. sold for $22 million, setting Boston's single-family home sale record.
The 9,000-square-foot residence underwent a two-year renovation, preserving its 1825 Greek Revival style.
Crest City Capital purchased the property for $8.9 million in 2023 and collaborated with Dalfior Development for restoration.
